item.content:encoded:
If you have ever seen a conservation advert on TV, chances are it was either a cute panda, a sad donkey, or a rhino with its horn cut off. These are the images that big conservation organisations show us in order to get money out of our wallets and into their bank accounts. Although scientific evidence supporting much of their conservation work is somewhat lacking, their marketing is spot on. The world’s biggest conservation organisation, for example, is now worth $6.5 billion. Academics have voiced their concerns over conservationists primary focus shifting from preserving biodiversity, to acquiring funding; regardless, they continue to grow.  

Poaching is one key area conservationists are focusing on. The ‘poaching crisis’ is affecting species globally – but particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, black rhinos, which have dwindled from millions to thousands in the past century. The driving force behind the unprecedented increase in poaching is the ever-expanding illegal wildlife trade. At $65,000 per kilogram, rhino horn is worth more than both gold and heroin on the Vietnamese black market. Organised criminals have responded accordingly and are now using novel techniques to capture and traffic wildlife to the region.

So, what’s the best solution we have to curb the wildlife trade? Green militarisation. This involves arming park rangers, increasing military style surveillance, and incorporating AI and global communications systems into park security. If this all sounds quite dramatic, that’s because it is. In Kruger National Park, South Africa, the rhino poaching crisis reached a tipping point in 2012. An increase from 13 rhinos killed in 2008 to over 1200 in 2012 provoked a reaction from South Africa.

Former Major General Johan Jooste was appointed to the position of anti-poaching coordinator in 2012. Jooste’s long history in the armed forces and critical – if troubling – role in the ‘apartheid wars’ secured him the role. His anti-poaching mantra was obvious from the outset: violence first, negotiation later.  

Jooste quickly bolstered defences and framed poaching as “a declaration of war against South Africa by armed foreign criminals”. Fences were erected, armed rangers were employed and surveillance planes scrambled. Ex-veterans from the global north flocked to the country to scratch their violent itch under the guise of conservation work. 

Across the border in Mozambique, large tracts of land adjacent to Kruger National Park began to be bought or leased by South African businesses, foreign NGO’s, nation-states (Germany, the Netherlands, South Africa) and philanthropists. A new national park, the Greater Lebombo Conservancy, was created and swiftly militarised. Those who lived within this area, roughly the size of Dorset, where forcibly relocated to its borders, and subsistence hunting was outlawed. These people now join the 1 million+ other victims of biodiversity protection as ‘conservation refugees’. The park would act as a ‘buffer’ to the Kruger Park, discouraging Mozambicans from poaching and extending South Africa’s power beyond its borders.

Despite this mega-militarisation, the year following Jooste’s appointment saw a record-breaking number of rhinos killed and de-horned within Kruger Park. The consequences, however, were not restricted to the animal kingdom. Since the Lebombo Conservancy was created in 2012, over 300 (suspected) poachers have been killed. This forces us to question how effective ‘green militarisation’ really is, and raises some poignant moral dilemmas: is a rhino’s life, or the assurance of a rhino’s life, worth more than a human’s? Why is wildlife more valuable than human life in Africa, but not in the UK or the global north more generally? Perhaps it’s because we don’t have any spectacular wildlife worth protecting. Or, is it because poaching is a racialised crime in Africa, that a legacy of colonialism facilitates?  

Interestingly, poaching rhinos is legal in South Africa for those rich white men who can afford the hunting licenses. The fatal consequences for some, and simple monetary exchange for others, is seen as cultural imperialism at its best, and a new form of colonialism at worst. Perhaps next time you see the rhino advert on TV you will question the agenda more critically. Are we saving rhinos, or are we exercising control comparable to that of colonists just 120 years ago? 

Writing by Dillon Creedon and illustrations by James Farrant.
